headline: November 10 general election: The campaign so far

November 10 general election: The campaign so far

Five candidates for the job of prime minister of Spain will face off at a televised debate tonight at 10pm. The record number of participants reflects the political fragmentation in a country that is about to hold its fourth national election in four years on Sunday, and that not so long ago had a stable two-party system that saw the conservative Popular Party (PP) and left-wing Socialist Party (PSOE) take turns in power.
With just six days to go before the election, surveys show that no single party will secure a majority
The televised debate comes on the same day that King Felipe VI is scheduled to hand out a prize in Barcelona amid heavy security measures, with tensions still running high in Catalonia in the wake of a Supreme Court ruling that jailed nine pro-independence leaders. The issue of the Catalan secessionist drive is expected to figure prominently on the speakersâ€™ agenda during the debate tonight.
With just six days to go before Spaniards head for the polls, surveys show that no single party will secure enough of a majority to form a government, and political leaders have been trying to attract undecided centrist voters since the campaign kicked off last week.
Here is a round-up of the campaigning so far.

Irene Montero, the spokesperson for Unidas Podemos, accused the PSOE of using the crisis in Catalonia to seek a governing deal with the PP after the November 10 elections. At the close of the debate, the Basque Nationalist Left (PNV) spokesperson Aitor Esteban refused to shake the hand of Voxâ€™s Espinosa de los Monteros. The party later issued a statement explaining that the Vox politician had previously called Esteban and his colleagues â€œracist and xenophobic.â€ â€œIt is not a question of being polite, but rather principles and dignity,â€ the party said in a message. â€œBasques do not shake hands with Francoists.â€
On Saturday, at a campaign rally in Valencia, caretaker Prime Minister Pedro SÃ¡nchez drew attention to how far-right Vox has gained influence in recent months, thanks to its support for coalition deals between the PP and Ciudadanos in the regional governments of Madrid, Andalusia and Murcia, as well as in Madrid City Hall.
â€œThe far-right is beaten by defending democratic principles and by isolating it,â€ he told a crowd of 2,000 in Mislata, Valencia. â€œBy condemning Francoism, sexism, its xenophobia and racism. Condemning its trivialization of gender violence. If the far right has its head held high right now itâ€™s because the PP, instead of isolating it, has joined its destiny with the far right.â€
Pablo Iglesias, the head of the leftist Unidas Podemos bloc, said at a rally in A CoruÃ±a on Sunday that â€œthere are a lot of people who are [supporters of our party] but just donâ€™t know it.â€
Iglesias also accused SÃ¡nchez of â€œbeing leftist only during primaries and election campaigns.â€ He said that SÃ¡nchez will do whatever Brussels asks of him, such as â€œthe cutsâ€ that are coming up due to the â€œeconomic slowdown.â€
At his own Sunday rally in Madrid, Popular Party (PP) leader Pablo Casado also criticized the PSOE, which is set to win the election with 121 seats, according to a recent poll.
Casado said that SÃ¡nchez is benefiting from the unrest in Catalonia, where 300 police officers were injured and four people lost eyes during week-long street disturbances following the Supreme Courtâ€™s decision in the case against Catalan separatist leaders. He said that SÃ¡nchez will be responsible for any incidents that take place during the kingâ€™s visit today.
â€œWhatâ€™s going on when you see the king going to Catalonia as though he were going to a civil confrontation zone?â€ asked Casado. â€œMr SÃ¡nchez, this isnâ€™t Burkina Faso, this is not Yemen, this is Spain. Put some order in Catalonia once and for all. Stop negotiating with the separatists.â€
Ciudadanos (Citizens), which began as an anti-independence party in Catalonia but soon jumped to the national stage, is facing something of a crisis at the November 10 election, with its support having plummeted in the polls. Its leader, Albert Rivera, has already addressed questions about whether he will step down if these predictions come true. â€œIâ€™m an attorney,â€ he told reporters. â€œI worked before politics. There are other candidates who have never worked a day. Iâ€™m in politics because Iâ€™m passionate about it. Iâ€™m not driven by clinging to a seat or a job, just this country.â€ But sources close to the Ciudadanos leader say that he will not quit, even if the result next Sunday is bad.
The partyâ€™s campaign team is concentrating on the two million or so indecisive voters, and Rivera is prepared for the campaign. He cleared his diary for the last three days and has spent the time preparing for tonightâ€™s debate. He raised a few eyebrows, however, when he released a video at the weekend presenting his â€œsecret weaponâ€ for the debate: a puppy named Lucas. â€œThose who attack me in the debate will have to answer to Lucas,â€ he said in the light-hearted Instagram recording.
